body: Hi, thanks for your msg, to me, w.r.t. a l^2 loss, they look the same(* except if 1.a is not mapped on 2.a - in this case, which value of J do use, etc). Have you considered using a log? Maybe @lostanlen will have more insightful comments
@edouardoyallon  I haven't used log loss, I'll try that out too. Since, the length of the signal is 1000 time units I am using J = 9.

Alright. What is weird too me is that despite the high value of $J$, the figures of (b) seem to spike at the same time. J=9 might be slightly high, and I'd consider using smaller values (which might be simpler to compute). Again, @lostanlen will have probably more insightful comments.
@edouardoyallon I think I tried out smaller values for J. I'll double check it with log loss and let you know. Thanks!

Hello @Vin-itall , my guess is that `J` is indeed to high for the task. 
Besides, can you try adding an offset to the input signal and see if the same offset also appears in the reconstructed signal? If it doesn't, make sure that the difference at the zeroth order (`S_0`) appears in the loss function for reconstruction
Hi @lostanlen  thanks for your input, I'll try out your suggestions and get back to you.

@edouardoyallon I am sorry I didn't mean to sound rude, I just meant that I haven't been able to get back with the results because I am waiting for the fix. I am sorry if it came out wrong. was just trying to keep you guys updated.
@lostanlen  Hey, lower value for J did the trick. Thanks a lot for your input. Is there some resource where I can read up on how J impacted the reconstruction? If so please let me know.

Glad it's working, @Vin-itall 
You can refer to Figure 10 of: And√©n, Lostanlen, and Mallat. "Joint time-frequency scattering" IEEE SPL
rows (b), (d) and (f) correspond to increasing values of J
https://www.lostanlen.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/anden2019tsp.pdf
